description: default value: Analyzes dependencies between classes to detect architectural violations
Brief description of what this tool does
Inversion guard analyzes dependencies between classes to detect architectural violations
Helps AI assistants and developers understand the purpose of the application
readme: Link to the README file for detailed documentation
Should be a URL to the project's README on GitHub or similar
configHelp: Name of the JSON file containing detailed help for each configuration setting
This file is automatically generated with documentation for all config keys

inputDir: The directory from which to start scanning for class files
All class files under this directory will be analyzed for dependencies
outputDir: The directory where the analysis report will be generated
HTML and JSON reports will be written to this location

includeFile: List of regular expression patterns for class files to include in analysis
Files must match at least one include pattern to be analyzed
Example: ".*/target/.*\\.class" to include all .class files in target directories
excludeFile: List of regular expression patterns for class files to exclude from analysis
Files matching any exclude pattern will be skipped even if they match an include pattern
skipDir: List of directory name patterns to skip during file scanning
Directories matching these patterns will not be traversed

globalRules: Path to the JSON file containing global category and boundary rules
This file defines the architectural categories (core/boundary) for the project

core: List of package patterns to classify as 'core' in addition to global rules
Core classes should not depend on boundary classes
Local rules are combined with global rules from the globalRules file
boundary: List of package patterns to classify as 'boundary' in addition to global rules
Boundary classes handle external interactions (I/O, network, databases)
Local rules are combined with global rules from the globalRules file

failOnUnknown: Whether to fail the build if classes are found that don't match any category
When true, all classes must be categorized as either core or boundary
When false, uncategorized classes are reported but don't cause build failure
maximumAllowedErrorCount: Maximum number of architectural violations allowed before build fails
Set to 0 to enforce zero violations
Useful for gradually improving existing codebases
